login.title: Welcome to Cuttle.Cards
login.subtitle: The card game that will have you hooked from the first hand!
login.formHeaderSignup: Sign up now to start playing and get ready to dive into the world of Cuttle.
login.quote: "Cuttle is a sharp, fast game built entirely on excellent mechanics. It is the sort of game - had I known about it in college - I would have worn decks ragged through play."
login.quoteCite: Richard Garfield - Creator of Magic: The Gathering
login.content: Cuttle is a 2 player battle card game played with a standard 52-card deck of cards. It has the strategic nuance of trading card games like Magic, with the elegant balance of a standard deck -- and you can play it for free! Test your mettle in the deepest cardgame under the sea!
login.content2: Be the first to score 21 points in this explosive battle of wits. Mount a valient offense while disupting your opponent with dastardly tricks. Do you have what it takes to become the Lord of the Deep?

four.oppponentHasResolved: Your Opponent has resolved a Four One-Off. You must discard two cards. Click to select cards to discard.

five.resolveFive: You have resolved a 5 one-off. Choose a card to discard and then you will draw 3 cards
five.resolveFiveNoCards: You have Resolved a 5 one-off, but have no cards in your hand to discard. You draw 3 cards without discarding. Sweet!

scrapDialog.noCards: There are no cards in the scrap pile.

counterDialogs.selectCard: Which Two would you like to counter with? (Click the card)
counterDialogs.playTwo: Would you like to play a two to counter?

reasons.noTwoPresent: you do not have a two

matchStatus.playerLeft: Player left - click to go home.
matchStatus.opponentLeft: Opponent left - click to go home.

disabledMove.topTwo: You must play one of the top two cards from the deck
disabledMove.emptyDeck: Can't be played with empty deck
disabledMove.multipleQueens: You can't play a {rank} while your opponent has two or more queens
disabledMove.noRoyals: There are no Royals to target
disabledMove.noRoyalsOrPoints: There are no point cards or Royals to target

scuttle.disabled: You can only scuttle smaller point cards
scuttle.disabledNoPoints: Your opponent has no point cards to scuttle

effects.2: Scrap target Royal or Glasses eight
effects.3: Choose 1 card in the Scrap and put it to your hand
effects.4: Your opponent discards two cards of their choice from their hand
effects.5: Discard 1 card, and draw up to 3
effects.6: Scrap all Royals and Glasses eights
effects.7: Play one of the top two cards of the deck and put the other back (both are revealed)
effects.8: Your opponent plays with an open hand (their cards are revealed to you)
effects.9: Return target card to its controller's hand. They can't play it next turn
effects.11: Play on top of target point card to steal it
effects.12: Your other cards may only be targeted by scuttles
effects.13: Reduces the points you need to win. (1K: 14pts, 2K: 10pts, 3K: 5pts, 4K: 0pts)

jack.disabled: You cannot jack your opponent's points while they have a queen

gameMenu.concedeDialog: The game will end and your opponent will win.
gameMenu.stalemateDialog: If your opponent agrees, the game will end in a stalemate. The request will cancel if the opponent declines or either player makes a move.

global.cardFrozen: That card is frozen! You must wait a turn to play it.
global.playFromHand: You can only play a card that is in your hand
global.blockedByQueen: Your opponent's queen prevents you from targeting their other cards
global.blockedByMultipleQueens: You cannot play a Targeted One-Off (Two, Nine) when your opponent has more than one Queen

seven.pickAndPlay: You can only play cards from the top of the deck while resolving a seven.

five.selectCardToDiscard: You must select one card to discard
five.fiveDeckIsEmpty: Cannot resolve 5 one-off with an empty deck

draw.deckIsEmpty: The deck is empty; you cannot draw.
draw.handLimit: You are at the hand limit; you cannot draw.

faceCards.withoutTarget: Only Kings, Queens, and Eights may be played as Face Cards without a target

points.numberOnlyForPoints: You can only play a number card as points.

jack.stealOnlyWithJack: You can only steal your opponent's points with a jack
jack.stealOnlyPointCards: You can only steal your opponent's point cards
jack.noJackWithQueen: You cannot use a Jack while your opponent has a Queen.

scuttle.rankTooLow: You can only scuttle if your card's rank is higher, or the rank is the same, and your suit is higher (Clubs < Diamonds < Hearts < Spades)
scuttle.mustUsePointCard: You can only scuttle with an ace through ten
scuttle.mustTargetPointCard: You can only scuttle a card your opponent has played for points

oneOffs.scrapIsEmpty: You can only play a 3 ONE-OFF if there are cards in the scrap pile
oneOffs.opponentHasNoCards: You cannot play a 4 as a ONE-OFF while your opponent has no cards in hand
oneOffs.sevenWithEmptyDeck: You can only play a 7 as a ONE-OFF if there are cards in the deck
oneOffs.sevenWithOneCardInDeck: You cannot play a 7 as a ONE-OFF if it is the last card in the deck
oneOffs.cantPlayWithoutATarget: You cannot play that card as a ONE-OFF without a target
oneOffs.onlyTwoOrNine: You can only play a 2, or a 9 as targeted one-offs.
oneOffs.oneOffInPlay: There is already a one-off in play; you cannot play any card, except a two to counter.

rules.cuttleText: Cuttle is a two player battle card game played with a standard 52-card deck of cards. It has the strategic nuance of trading card games like Magic, with the elegant balance of a standard deck--and you can play it for free! Test your mettle in the deepest card game under the sea!
rules.rulesWatchText: or watch cuttle.cards video tutorial below to learn the rules and get a feel for the flow of the game.
rules.goalText: The goal is to be the first player to have 21 or more points worth of point cards on your field. The first player to reach the goal wins immediately. One player (traditionally the dealer) is dealt 6 cards and their opponent is dealt 5. The player with 5 cards goes first.
rules.playText-1: One player (traditionally the dealer) is dealt 6 cards and their opponent is dealt 5. The player with 5 cards goes first.
rules.playText-2: On your turn you must perform exactly one of the following actions:
rules.drawDescription: Take one card from the deck. You may not draw past the 8-card hand limit.  If there are no cards left in the deck, you may pass.  Three consecutive passes ends the game in a stalemate
rules.pointsDescription: Play a number card from your hand. Worth its rank in points and lasts until scrapped.
rules.scuttleDescription: Scrap an opponent's point card with a bigger one from your hand. Ties are broken by the suit:
rules.royalDescription: Play a royal to the field for a persistent benefit -- as long as it stays in play
rules.oneoffDescription: Scrap a number card for an effect based on the rank of the card.
rules.glassesDescription: Play an Eight to reveal your opponent's hand (lasts until scrapped).

royals.title: Royals
royals.text: Royals (Kings, Queens, and Jacks) may be played to the field for a persistent benefit that remains in effect until the card is scrapped. Each Royal gives a different effect.
royals.kingDescription: Reduce the number of points you need to win (21, 14, 10, 5, 0 points with 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 Kings).
royals.queenDescription: Protects your other cards from being targeted by the effects of other cards. This protects your cards against 2's (both effects), 9's, and Jacks.
royals.queenDescription2: Does not protect against aces, sixes or scuttling.
royals.jackDescription: Play on an opponent's point card to steal it. Point card returns to opponent if the Jack is scrapped or if another Jack is used to steal it back.
royals.eightDescription: Play a 'Glasses Eight' to reveal your opponent's hand. This counts as a Royal and lasts until scrapped.

oneoffs.title: One-Offs
oneoffs.text: Number cards (except 8's and 10's) can be played for a One-Off effect, which scraps the card for an effect based on the rank of the card played. Whenever a one-off is played, the other player may counter it using a two to cancel the effect.
oneoffs.aceDescription: Scrap all point cards on the field.
oneoffs.twoE1Description: Effect 1: Counter target One-Off Effect. Counters may be played during your opponent's turn.
oneoffs.twoE2Description: Effect 2: Scrap target Royal or Glasses Eight.
oneoffs.threeDescription: Choose a card from the scrap pile and put it in your hand.
oneoffs.fourDescription: Your opponent discards two cards of their choice.
oneoffs.fiveDescription: Discard one card then draw up to three cards from the deck up to the 8 card hand limit.
oneoffs.sixDescription: Scrap all Royals and Glasses Eights on the field.
oneoffs.sevenDescription: Reveal the top two cards of the deck to both players and choose one to play however you choose.
oneoffs.nineDescription: Return a card from your opponent's field to their hand. They cannot play it next turn.

rules.multiplayerText1: Presently only 2-player cuttle is available at
rules.multiplayerText2: however Cuttle can be played with 2-4 players. 3 and 4-player Cuttle each have slight variations on the rules to optimize the game balance while changing the pace and the feel. Give them a try next time you're playing Cuttle in a group!

3Players.title: 3 Player Cuttle: Cutthroat
3Players.text: Cutthroat is a brutally fast-paced 1v1v1 version of Cuttle, full of betrayal and pivotal moments!
3Players.rules: The rules are the same as above with the following changes:
3Players.rule1: The win condition is reduced. Players need 14 points to win by default, 9 points with one King in play, 5 points with two Kings in play, and having 3 Kings in play immediately wins (goal becomes zero).
3Players.rule2: To start play, deal each player 5 cards and the player to the left of the dealer goes first. Which player is the dealer rotates clockwise each game.
3Players.rule3: Shuffle two Jokers into the deck. Jokers count as Royals with the effect "Steal target Royal".
3Players.rule4: The hand limit is reduced to 7 (from 8).

4Players.title: 4 Player Cuttle: 2v2
4Players.text: 4 player Cuttle is a 2v2 team game. Each player sits across from their partner. Your team wins if either you or your teammate reach your respective goals, but players do not share cards on their hand or field (points are counted separately and your Royals do not directly affect your partner).
4Players.rules: The rules are otherwise the same as 1v1 Cuttle, with play proceeding clockwise from the left of the dealer, with the following other changes:
4Players.rule1: Each player is dealt 5 cards, play starts left of the dealer and proceeds clockwise from there.
4Players.rule2: Shuffle two Jokers into the deck. Jokers count as Royals with the effect "Steal target Royal". Similar to Jacks, they may transfer control of a Royal from any player to any other player.
4Players.rule3: The hand limit is reduced to 7 (from 8).
4Players.rule4: Jacks may be played to transfer control of any point card to any other player. You may therefore "steal" points from yourself (or anyone else) in order to give them to your partner, potentially winning on your turn with their points (their goal is still determined by the count of their own Kings on the field).
4Players.rule5: Nines can be played for an alternative, similar effect. Whenever an opponent plays a Royal, you may immediately play a Nine in response to return that card to its owner's hand immediately, preventing its effect from taking place. Doing so may be done out of turn and does not take your turn, but does not prevent the target's owner from playing the card again on their next turn. Alternatively, you may still play a Nine for its original one-off effect on your turn (taking your turn to do so) to return a card to its controller's hand and prevent them from playing that card on their next turn.

faq.title: FAQ
faq.twoCounter: Can I play a two to counter a point card? What about a scuttle?
faq.twoCounterAnswer: Nope! Twos can only counter One-Offs. You can play a two to destroy a Royal or Glasses Eight, but this takes your turn, unlike countering.
faq.queenProtectTwo: Do Queens protect against countering with a two?
faq.queenProtectTwoAnswer: Yes! Queens protect against targeting, when a card applies a unique effect to one specific card. This means your other cards (not the Queen, herself) are protected against Twos (either effect), Nines, and Jacks.
faq.queenProtectScuttle: Do Queens protect against scuttling? What about Aces & Sixes?
faq.queenProtectScuttleAnswer: No! Scuttling doesn't count as targeting, and neither do the board-wiping effects of Aces or Sixes. Queens only protect against the effects of Twos, Nines, and Jacks.
faq.twoOnTwo: Can I counter a Two with a Two?
faq.twoOnTwoAnswer: Heck yeah! Playing a Two to counter is a One-Off, which can be countered with a two. Stacked counters make for exciting plays and pivotal strategic moments.
faq.kingWin: Can I win by playing a King?
faq.kingWinAnswer: Yes! If you meet the required number of points, you win immediately. This means if you play a King when you already have enough points to meet the new limit, you win on that turn.
faq.aceDestruction: If I play an Ace or a Six, are my cards destroyed as well?
faq.aceDestructionAnswer: Yes. Aces and Sixes destroy all Point Cards and all Royals plus Glasses Eights, respectively. That includes any that you have out. Try to avoid destroying too many of your own cards!
faq.revealNoPoints: My Seven revealed two Jacks and my opponent has no points. What happens?
faq.revealNoPointsAnswer: If playing both cards revealed by a Seven is impossible (namely revealing two Jacks and your opponent has no point cards in play), choose one card to discard and place the other back on top of the deck.
faq.revealOneLeft: What if I play a Seven and there is only one card left in the deck?
faq.revealOneLeftAnswer: Reveal just the one card and continue play like normal. Similar to the above situation, if you reveal a Jack and your opponent does not have any point cards in play, that Jack is scrapped.
faq.emptyHandFive: What happens when I play a five with an otherwise empty hand?
faq.emptyHandFiveAnswer: If you have no other cards in hand when you play a 5, you simply skip discarding and draw three cards. This can be a powerful, but risky play. If it works, you end up with two more cards than you started with that turn, but if it is countered, you could have no cards at all!
faq.deckExhaust: What happens when the deck is exhausted?
faq.deckExhaustAnswer: When there are no cards left in the deck, players may pass on their turn instead of drawing. If there are three consecutive passes i.e. player 1 passes, player 2 passes, then player 1 passes again, the game ends in a stalemate and neither player wins.
faq.whereToPlayAnswer: You can play Cuttle anywhere you have a deck of cards and a friend. If you want to play online, there is only one place: cuttle.cards

tournaments.title: Tournaments
tournaments.competitiveCuttle1: Competitive Cuttle is divided into 4 seasons per year,one per suit: Clubs, Diamonds, Hearts, and Spades. At the end of each season, the top 8 players play a double elimination championship tournament and the champions are permanently accoladed on the site.
tournaments.competitiveCuttle2: Each Season is divided into 13 weeks. For each week, we count the number of best 2/3 rankedmatches each player wins against unique opponents (ignoring stalemates) and assign players points based on their weekly standing.

scoring.firstPlace: The player with the most wins gets 5 points for the week
scoring.secondPlace: The player with the 2nd most wins gets 4 points for the week
scoring.thirdPlace: The player with the 3rd most wins gets 3 points for the week
scoring.oneWin: Each other player who won at least one match gets 2 points for the week
scoring.completedMatch: Each other player who completed a match without winning gets 1 point for the week

error.message: There was a problem loading the leaderboard. Refresh the page or select another season to try again.

season.tournamentBracket: here to see the official tournament bracket
season.tournamentFootage: here to watch the official tournament footage

fiveChange.ruleInfo: Playing a 5 now has a revised one-off effect: discard a card, then draw three cards
fiveChange.whyImplement: Because 5's take your turn to play and you could alternatively draw a card on your turn, while playing a 5 feels like it gets you two cards (yay!) it effectively only replaces itself without doing anything else for you. In order to power up the five and give it a specific purpose, while leaning into the theme of cycling your hand to draw you lots of cards, we're experimenting with a variation on the 5's effect where you first discard a card from your hand, then draw three cards! We hope this will increase the usefulness of the 5's effect and hone its strategic function. And we need your help deciding if this should become a permanent change!
fiveChange.previousBeta: We previously ran a 2-week beta trialing recycler 5's back in April. The community voted and the result was 69% to 31% in favor of the change. We got some valuable feedback, most importantly that many players felt they would like more time to trial recycler 5's before a final decision is made. We care deeply about respecting the community's wishes and about being thoughtful and conservative about making any changes to the rules of the game. In that spirit, we are extending the recycler 5 beta through the Diamonds 2024 Cuttle Season Championship!
fiveChange.howLongHeader: How long is the extended beta?
fiveChange.howLong: The recycler 5 beta will run from Tuesday May 14th, until Wednesday, July 31st.
fiveChange.howLong2: In order to give players ample opportunity to try the effect, the final round of voting will re-open in at the end of the Diamonds 2024 season in early July.
fiveChange.gameModesHeader: What game modes does this affect?
fiveChange.gameModes: The beta affects both ranked and casual play. Ranked play will continue to count on the leaderboard as normal, so you don't need to skip playing ranked to try it out!
fiveChange.learnMore1: You can learn more about this balance change and the surrounding discussion on
fiveChange.learnMore2: where players are discussing the change and whether they would like to see it made permanent. Tell us what you think!
